Award.AwardTitle: URM: Achieving Sucess in Science through Undergraduate Research Experiences (ASSURE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

Miami University's URM program will recruit 12 undergraduates each year for the next five years to provide the students with research and mentoring experience in order to prepare them for graduate school in the biological sciences. As a first step toward institutionalizing the program, NSF funds will be used to support each student for the first two years in the program, after which Miami University will provide support for an additional two years. Activities planned for academic, research and career enrichment will be offered to a larger group of students, especially those from underrepresented minority groups. The major goals of the URM program are to: (i) Increase the number of underrepresented minority students recruited into the biological sciences; (ii) Enhance the preparation of students to enable them to successfully enter and remain in graduate programs; and (iii) Build a better foundation at the institution for promoting interactions among academic, student support and administrative structures. The research programs of about 30 faculty across four departments (Biochemistry, Botany, Microbiology and Zoology) will provide students with a wide and diverse choice of projects, all under a unifying theme of "Signaling mechanisms and cellular responses". URM scholars will be exposed to a variety of model organisms, tools and techniques, and scholars' interest in a research career will be sustained and strengthened through enrichment activities and a strong mentoring component. More information about the program can be found at http://www.units.muohio.edu/urm_assure/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the Miami University ASSURE Program (Achieving Success in Science through Undergraduate Research Experiences) was to increase retention of majors in the life sciences, specifically students who were underrepresented minorities (URM). Program activities additionally reached out to students who were Pell Grant eligible or First Generation to college. All students in the program were actively engaged in research for three years starting in their sophomore year, and this formed the foundation for developing strong analytical and communication skills. Scholarships were also provided to students enrolled in the ASSURE Program. Intrusive and persistent advising were key features of the program.  In regard to institutional graduation outcomes, students from underrepresented groups, performed well when no risk factors were present, but performance declined when additional risk factors were present. Within the URM ASSURE program, the intrusive advising, small group support, undergraduate laboratory research and mentoring, and a scholarship, made a significant difference in outcomes, especially for underrepresented students who were at risk due to other factors.  The ASSURE program produced higher retention and graduation rates in Chemistry, Botany, Microbiology and Zoology. No surveys were devised during the study to separate the effect of advising versus the effect of the scholarship. However, the combined intervention worked well to retain and graduate students in the life sciences.

 

In addition to the overall goal of improving retention of underrepresented student groups, the programming provided opportunities for professional development of students, and over

40 faculty from four departments who were engaged in the mentoring/advising framework of the URM ASSURE program. Additionally, the program has resulted in institutionalizing the following: (1) Recruitment of underrepresented student groups: Collaborations with the Office of Admission and the College of Arts and Science to offer experiential modules for rising high school seniors who visit campus as part of  the University Bridges program (2) Retention of first year majors: A supplemental skills course, developed to enhance retention in the introductory biological science course has also been developed for the first year Chemistry course and  is supported in the Departments of Biology and the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry . (3) Introduction to Research for First Year Students: A Faculty Learning community forum over 2 years established the First Year Research Experience (FYRE) program.  Students from across the university participate in this program, and it is now housed in the newly established Office for Undergraduate Research (ORU). (4) Development of Intrusive advising structures for underrepresented student groups. The part time associate director of the URM program is now working with the LSAMP program, and implementing many of the lessons learned from the URM program.
